subject: Julie Chen: Crazy Bosses
body:

      May 22, 2007
  
       Hi, everybody,
 


Hope 
      the wayward whales Delta and Dawn are 
      finding their way back to the 
      Pacific Ocean and out of the Sacramento River.
 
Gil Schwartz, our 
      corporate executive vice president of 
communications
spoke about a topic we can all relate to ... crazy 
      bosses (in fact, that's the name of his new 
      book, written under the pseudonym Stanley Bing)!  Let's face 
      it, we've all had a job at one point or another where we thought our 
      boss was insane. My crazy boss was in Dayton, 
      Ohio, where I couldn't believe I 
      worked for someone who was 
      so completely 
      clueless. On the upside: it was 
      then that I realized 
      that if this guy could make it, I had a bright future 
      in TV news. Seriously, Gil 
      has a great sense of humor and an even greater boss who,
thankfully, also has a wonderful sense of humor (and that, of course, would be the man I'm married to!)
 
There 
      is a promising new drug for 
      women who are looking to limit how many times a year they menstruate.  The FDA is 
      expected to vote today on whether they should approve a drug called Lybrel. The birth control pill would have a side-effect of not 
      having a cycle every month.  This could lead to women not having to 
      experience the monthly cramps 
      normally associated with menstruation. But as with anything new on 
      the drug market, beware. There's never a 100 percent guarantee that we won't find out 
      years later there are negative side effects.
 
A case in point 
      is the news this week that the Type 2 Diabetes drug Avendia may increase 
      the risk of heart disease in some patients.
 
Great 
      to see "Amazing Race" host Phil Keoghan get to do something fun in an exotic 
      location. We're so accustomed to seeing just the Racers taking part in local culture in exotic spots 
      around the world. This morning we got to see Phil take a stab at hula dancing in Hawaii. Who knew it was an art 
      form traditionally performed by men 
      and not women.  Seeing the guys in grass skirts on "Gilligan's Island" should have been a dead giveaway! If you'd like to see some more of the hula 
      dancers, visit our Web site, where Phil gave us some Internet 
      exclusives. 
 
On tomorrow's show, we'll have the 
      latest on the Russian spy poisoning case, "Capitol" 
      Bob Schieffer will join us, our personal finance expert Ray Martin will 
      explain the fine points of student loans and we'll get tips about 
      buying a flattering bathing 
      suit. 
 
Take care,



Julie 
      Chen
